questions.question_text: What is one way to determine if the Product Owner is interacting with the Developers enough throughout a Sprint?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer should be A. There are times when developers needed to ask questions outside of the Daily

choices.B: Check the Daily Scrum reports to see whether the Product Owner was present at the majority of the Daily Scrum meetings.
choices.D: Observe whether the Developers need to ask the Product Owner questions at times other than during the Daily Scrum.
choices.A: Product Owners and Developers are satisfied with the increment.
choices.C: The Developers should determine the percentage of time the Product Owner is required to be present and monitor whether the Product Owner's average presence is around this figure.

questions.question_text:
Self-management is more effective when it happens within boundaries.

Select two relevant boundaries for self-management provided by the Scrum framework. (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A and B Scrum emphasizes self-management and shared responsibility. Sub-responsibilities and handovers contradict this by creating unnecessary silos and dependencies.

Selected Answer: AB
Question is about boundaries. D has nothing to do with it

choices.A: Timeboxing work to allow for frequent inspection.
choices.D: Clearly defining sub-responsibilities and handovers within the Scrum Team.
choices.B: Creating a valuable and useful Increment by the end of each Sprint.
choices.C: Having an even number of members in a Scrum Team to be able to do pair programming and be more productive.

questions.answer_description: The defined terminology in Scrum was selected, designed, and defined specifically for supporting the Scrum Framework. Understanding the differences between traditional methods and the Scrum Framework will help move teams in the right direction in Scrum adoption.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

questions.question_text: What would likely happen if management only changed the organization's current terminology to fit Scrum without the proper understanding and support of Scrum as defined in the Scrum Guide?

choices.A: Very little change will happen as the vocabulary in Scrum is specifically defined for implementing Scrum.
choices.B: The organization may not realize the real benefits of Scrum as there would be no real change on the way the teams work.
choices.C: Organizations may feel less stressed as the behaviors would remain familiar to management.
A clearly defined and predictable process that follows the principles of Computer Science.
choices.D: A framework to address complex products in complex environments.
choices.B: A manual for defining best practices for software development.
choices.A: A clearly defined methodology that defines the software development process.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Scrum is a lightweight framework that helps people, teams and organizations generate value through adaptive solutions for complex problems.

Selected Answer: D
Scrum is defined as per the scrum guide 2020

questions.question_text: In order to start the first Sprint, Scrum only requires a Product Owner with enough ideas, a Development Team to execute on those ideas, and a Scrum Master to guide the process.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct > Scrum.org states: "A first Sprint requires no more than a Scrum Team and enough ideas to potentially complete a full Sprint."

Selected Answer: B
Having "ideas" is not the same as having a properly ordered Product Backlog

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct 
The response is True as the ideas form the goal.

It's hard to say true or false. It depends on how the person worded the question assuming the PO has transformed his ideas on product backlog with product goal or not.
In case yes then the response is true. Otherwise the response is false.

Selected Answer: B
This is one of those that sound good when you read it but in Scrum Guide it is explicitly stated that you need formulated Sprint Goal which is formulated by PO and Sprint Backlog formulated during Sprint Planning. Also how can you start work when there are no Produt Backlog Items in Product Backlog created?

comments.content: Also - how can you begin on creating potentially shippable Increment without Definition of Done?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
To start the first Sprint, the Product Backlog should have enough items selected and appropriately ordered by the Product Owner to form a Sprint Goal and a potentially releasable Increment. The Sprint Goal defines the objective for the Sprint, and the Increment is the sum of all the completed Product Backlog items at the end of the Sprint.

So, while having a Product Owner, Development Team, and Scrum Master is necessary, the presence of a well-prepared Product Backlog is also required to begin the first Sprint in Scrum.
